7.15.19  8:50 pm   about a year and a half ago i was having trouble getting a project done, and i "snapped", like you have described yourself doing in the past. i went into power mode and finished it in about three months.

but after that, i had no project to work on, no clear successor, so i un-snapped and went back to doing what i was doing before. now i have a successor, but despite attempts, can't seem to "re-snap".

how do i do so?

     probably the same way you did it last time

      how do i muster up those same feelings on demand?

      i'm not sure

      you may have forgotten how much fun it can be

7.14.19  10:37 pm   What is it about the minor four in a major progression that sounds so good?

     essentially, you have 1 note, let's say C, staying the same. while a pair of notes, (E and G) slip together hand in hand one step over the line fully into the dark realm, and back. the C note staying the same throughout offers us a pivot with which to find common ground between the light world and dark world

      there is music every number, all the way to infinity.

7.14.19  6:49 pm   hey bill what key is the song Help! by the beatles in? Sounds like Amaj but it has a G chord in it and that isn't in Amaj. If it is A major, where does that G come from? 

      i would say the intro is Bmin, setting up to seem like it's going to be in D, (hanging on the final A7 sounds like we're about to go to verse in D) but surprise, it's just not. verse is in A. this coasts along comfortably and normally in A, for a while. Then, when it goes "help me if you can i'm feeling down" this is essentually 2 parallel universes running side by side. according to what came before, this sounds like the 2 min chord. so the G will now sound like an interesting flat7. but by the time we hit the E7, all of a sudden you can re-map the entire last 4 bars (two chords worth) as if they have been in Bmin (D) the whole time. similarly showing up at that A7 hang about to put you to bed in D, which again it does not, it just stays in A. just does. to have the fun of going around and doing it all again

7.14.19  6:03 pm   are you going to release isolated tracks of your music (like the isolated bass track of la de da)

      full project sessions should be one of the last product releases of my entire life. many other different exciting releases before then

stop having coincidences with your videos

      how about something a little more interesting

7.14.19  5:11 pm   what is the most common question you get?

      i have never received any question more than once

7.14.19  4:32 pm   Since a dominant 7th chord consists of a root,
a major third, a perfect fifth and a minor seventh, can you play the chord with just three notes? Or do you strictly need to play it with all four notes?

      i think i can safely say, the essence of that chord for the most part in today's society is, for example, C in the bass and E and Bb near the middle C range. that would be the commonly understood and socially functional and effective essence of the C7 chord, in so far as i have experienced
